newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks gyrate in mixed morning trade.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks gyrate in mixed morning trade.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks reversed a strong opening to slide into negative territory on Friday morning on selling of property and property-related shares, brokers said.
"I'm still a buyer of this market, but not today," said Gary Wong, sales director at Vickers Ballas. "Cheung Kong may be set to go to HK$100 but I'm not buying today."
The Hang Seng Index shed 32 points to 13,166 after leaping nearly 137 points at the open. Turnover was a robust HK$2.18 billion after 30 minutes of trade.

Brokers said that measures aimed at curbing speculation in the property market would have only a short term negative impact. Investors have been worried by the possibility that the government may impose measures to curb speculation in the property market and slow rising prices.

The market opened strongly after overreacting on Thursday to the rising trend in the U.S. long bond yield, one overseas-based broker said. The Hang Seng Index lost 256.82 points to close at 13,198.11 on Thursday.
But the benchmark U.S. 30-year bond finished at 96-25/32, up 1-4/32, to yield 6.75 percent on Thursday, versus Wedneday's closing yield of 6.84 percent, a trend equity markets were more pleased with.
Utilities showed strong gains to lead the market, while properties trended into negative territory. The Hang Seng China Enterprise Index also rebounded 0.94 percent to 1.022 in early trade.
The market was led up in early trade by buying in Hongkong Telecom. The share gained HK$0.70 to trade at HK$13.50 on speculation that Singapore Telecom would be taking a stake in the company.
China Light and Power put on HK$0.30 to HK$33.90, while Hongkong Electric eased HK$0.10 to 26.90, just above Hutchison's general offer price of HK$26.50.
Banking giant HSBC Holdings added HK$1.00 to HK$166.50 and Bank of East Asia climbed HK$0.50 to HK$34.70. Guangdong Kelon led the H share sector with a gain of HK$0.30 to HK$5.60.

Brokers said they were confused as to the short-term outlook for the property sector, but said they had a confident positive long-term view. Developers were hardest hit in early Friday morning trade. New World Development and Cheung Kong both lost HK$0.75 to HK$50.50 and HK$71.50. Henderson Land eased HK$0.50 to HK72.50 and Sun Hung Kai Properties lost HK$0.25 to HK$92.00.
